newsitem.title: UK: Gilt market anticipates higher UK inflation - L&G.
newsitem.headline: Gilt market anticipates higher UK inflation - L&G.

text.p: A rise in headline UK inflation above 3.5 percent year-on-year will soon be signalled by the gilt market in response to political, economic and monetary pressures, Legal & General said on Thursday.

John Monkton, L&G's bonds director, said underlying economic data and the gilt yield curve are beginning to indicate "an increasing risk of significantly higher inflation in the UK 18 to 24 months from now."
He said the gilt market believes official UK interest rates have bottomed but forecast a minor election boom if current monetary and fiscal policies are stuck with.
A UK general election must be held by May 1997 and the ruling Conservative government trails the opposition Labour Party badly in the polls.
"This will lead to a resumption of above-trend UK economic growth in 1997 and the rapid closing of the remaining gap in the UK between installed capacity and demand," Monkton said.
Headline UK inflation was just 2.1 percent year-on-year in August.
Legal & General Investment Management anticipates a flattening of the gilt yield curve with yields rising by around 50 basis points.
But if double digit monetary growth persists into 1997, Monkton said there could be extra upward pressure on yields.
M4 data, released on Thursday, showed broad money supply growth of 9.4 percent year-on-year.
